concept_data.title: Military Committee of the European Union

summary: The "Military Committee of the European Union," commonly referred to as the "EU Military Committee," is a pivotal body within the EU's Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP). Established pursuant to the Treaty on European Union, it comprises chiefs of defense from EU member states, who are appointed for a term of three years. The committee's primary function is to advise the Council on military matters and to ensure the effective functioning of military operations. Meetings are held regularly, and decisions are made based on recommendations from the chairman. Official journal entries document these proceedings, setting the framework for EU defense initiatives.
